docs.abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived here today on a visit in which is he expected to hold talks on establishing a philanthropic center. Mr. Carter is the chairman of Global 2000, an organization dedicated to ''eradicating poverty, injustice and social conflicts that plague the world.''
docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived here today on a visit in which is he expected to hold talks on establishing a philanthropic center. Mr. Carter is the chairman of Global 2000, an organization dedicated to ''eradicating poverty, injustice and social conflicts that plague the world.''

docs.abstract: More than 10,000 striking teachers from non-Government schools held a sit-in outside Bangladesh's main Government offices today, blocking roads and halting traffic for several hours. About 150,000 teachers from nearly 10,000 non-Government secondary schools are on strike because, they contend, they are being discriminated against compared to teachers working in government schools.
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 10,000 striking teachers from non-Government schools held a sit-in outside Bangladesh's main Government offices today, blocking roads and halting traffic for several hours. About 150,000 teachers from nearly 10,000 non-Government secondary schools are on strike because, they contend, they are being discriminated against compared to teachers working in government schools.

docs.abstract: Bangladesh hopes to increase its foreign-exchange earnings by allowing offshore banking in its free trade zone near Chittagong, the central bank said today. Offshore banking units would be allowed to accept deposits in 10 currencies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bangladesh hopes to increase its foreign-exchange earnings by allowing offshore banking in its free trade zone near Chittagong, the central bank said today. Offshore banking units would be allowed to accept deposits in 10 currencies.

docs.abstract: President H. M. Ershad of Bangladesh hailed last week's national election as ''the last bridge toward a democratic government.'' But to the main opposition leaders, it was another step toward stronger rule.
docs.lead_paragraph: President H. M. Ershad of Bangladesh hailed last week's national election as ''the last bridge toward a democratic government.'' But to the main opposition leaders, it was another step toward stronger rule.

headline.print_headline: THE WORLD; Reactions Vary on Bangladeshi Vote

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Milt Freudenheim

docs.abstract: An opposition member of Parliament was badly wounded today by five men who attacked him with bamboo sticks and axes, the authorities said.
docs.lead_paragraph: An opposition member of Parliament was badly wounded today by five men who attacked him with bamboo sticks and axes, the authorities said.

docs.abstract: The people in the squalid shantytown of Geneva Camp count themselves among the world's most unwanted refugees. In a generation, they fled two homelands and then found that Pakistan, the country of their choice, would not take them in.   Some 250,000 Moslems whose families were originally from the northern Indian state of Bihar are today in 66 refugee centers, such as Geneva Camp, throughout Bangladesh. Last month a fire swept through the camp's sheds and huts, killing dozens of people and filling the place with even more despair.
docs.lead_paragraph: The people in the squalid shantytown of Geneva Camp count themselves among the world's most unwanted refugees. In a generation, they fled two homelands and then found that Pakistan, the country of their choice, would not take them in.

byline.original: By Steven R. Weisman, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: Strikes have shut Bangladesh's newspapers, hospitals and universities and raised fears that violence may disrupt the presidential elections scheduled for next month.
docs.lead_paragraph: Strikes have shut Bangladesh's newspapers, hospitals and universities and raised fears that violence may disrupt the presidential elections scheduled for next month.

headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Journalists Add To Bangladesh Strikes

docs.abstract: A popular opposition leader was confined to her home today, and the police routed three dozen of her supporters from the city's largest mosque as the Government cracked down on political groups opposed to the holding of parliamentary elections on Wednesday.   Policemen armed with shields and long bamboo sticks charged into the Baitul Mukarrum Mosque shortly after early evening prayers and arrested at least 36 men identified as supporters of a boycott.
docs.lead_paragraph: A popular opposition leader was confined to her home today, and the police routed three dozen of her supporters from the city's largest mosque as the Government cracked down on political groups opposed to the holding of parliamentary elections on Wednesday.

headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Bangladesh Confines An Opposition Leader

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.abstract: A double-decker ferry sank in a storm in the Dhaleswari River on Sunday night, leaving nearly 500 passengers feared drowned, the authorities reported today.   Many of the 1,000 passengers aboard the ferry, the Atlas Star, swam ashore. The police said that 168 bodies had been recovered and that 300 people were still missing and feared dead in the accident, which took place near Munshiganj, about 10 miles south of Dhaka, the capital.
docs.lead_paragraph: A double-decker ferry sank in a storm in the Dhaleswari River on Sunday night, leaving nearly 500 passengers feared drowned, the authorities reported today.

docs.abstract: Heavily armed policemen fought with demonstrators in battles that left at least 200 people injured on the opening day of Parliament.
docs.lead_paragraph: Heavily armed policemen fought with demonstrators in battles that left at least 200 people injured on the opening day of Parliament.

headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Bangladesh Parliament Opens With Violence
